posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
Not sure if anybody noticed, but the website has recently got an update:

signal-website2364×1902 275 KB

And now it includes a link to Signal’s Instagram account:

https://instagram.com/signal_app/

The oldest post is dated October 31, 2018, so the account itself is likely not new. Also, it has some Privacy Please and Signal sticker photos

They also exist on several other platforms.

Signal in social media (Twitter, Facebook, etc.) General Discussion
Signal has two accounts on Facebook, two accounts on Twitter and one account on Reddit: Probably an official account Redirecting... Old account? Account created by a fan? Redirecting... Official Twitter account https://twitter.com/signalapp Old Twitter account - not active https://twitter.com/SignalMessenger Signal Desktop account (Unofficial) https://twitter.com/signaldesktop Signal on Reddit https://www.reddit.com/r/signal/ update: Signal on Instagram https://www.i…

link_counts.title: Signal in social media (Twitter, Facebook, etc.)

posts.cooked:
While I don’t know if this is the right place to report it, I just noticed 2 minor issues regarding the translation of signal.org:

  • I can’t switch from my default locale (German, de) to English, probably because the link just redirects to signal.org, which automatically switches to my system locale. There is no e.g. Signal >> Home.
  • If I switch to any other language (except for English), German is displayed as “Deutsche”, which should probably read “Deutsch”.

Anyway, great move to translate the Signal webpage!

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked: Thanks, @minnmann. I added those to our list and we’ll get them sorted out.

By default English language is displayed and the header (white text on blue background with Support, Blog, Developers and Careers) is in English, that is expected. Now switch too any other language e.g. Deutsch and header is still in English. Header should also change, the person that wants to switch the language does not know what header is saying, isn’t it.

Another little issue. At the header there are two additional links to external pages: Twitter and Instagram. Now move down to the very bottom of web page there are three black icons and one of them is Github. Why isn’t Github on the top header? Is it missing or intentional?

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked:
shellSignal:

Header should also change, the person that wants to switch the language does not know what header is saying, isn’t it.

Translating the header links would arguably lead users to think that those pages are also translated, so we decided not to do that right now. We’re starting out with translations for the home page and download page because those are the highest impact areas for new users. The “Desktop” download link on the home page is translated, for example.

shellSignal:

Why isn’t Github on the top header? Is it missing or intentional?

This isn’t a new change. We don’t want the top header to get too cluttered, and not every user is a developer.

jlund, thanks for explaining, make sense.

When I set in my browser for example “German [de]” as my default browser language and reload the www.signal.org web page, it does not automatically change to German. I have to manually change the setting. Is this the way you want this page to work?

There’s another bug that - as far as I can tell - seems to affect the German website only:

For the Snowden quote, en.home_sub_tagline (“Privacy that fits in your pocket.”) is incorrectly displayed instead of en.home_snowden_quote (“Use anything by Open Whisper Systems.”)

The translation on Transifex is correct, though (I’ve done it).

PS: Btw, why is the language (“en”) included in the keys/identifiers?

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Are there plans for translations to Dutch? Or is the Dutch speaking community too small to be considered for this?

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked:
@minnmann You should be able to switch to English now, though you may have to clear the cached redirect for the site in your browser. With the Developer Tools window open in Chromium, you can click and hold on the refresh button and select “Empty Cache and Hard Reload.”

German is now listed as “Deutsch” in the selector too.

shellSignal:

…it does not automatically change to German. I have to manually change the setting. Is this the way you want this page to work?

This should be fixed now.

RiseT:

There’s another bug that - as far as I can tell - seems to affect the German website only:

Fixed! Thanks.

RiseT:

PS: Btw, why is the language (“en”) included in the keys/identifiers?

It isn’t anymore. The YAML file format is different now too. Watch Transifex for an update soon.

Meteor0id:

Are there plans for translations to Dutch? Or is the Dutch speaking community too small to be considered for this?

We will probably continue to expand the list of supported languages in the future.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
something I will never understand: why not keeping all external scripts and CSS files locally (ajax.googleapi.com, bootrapscdn.com, …)?
I always do it this way. Protecting my users from tracking is important to me and the “extra work” is not worth mentioning. Imo, this way the Signal team unintentionally makes itself untrustworthy: on the one hand SignalApp with best possible protection of its users, see also the discussion about removing firebase-analytics, and on the other hand “tracking” in signal.org.

link_counts.title: GCM will be removed from Google
iOS Backups / Keeping message history when resetting phone
Is it feasible to link signalstickers.com from signal.org?
Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.52 release

posts.cooked:
That’s the standard when using third-party frameworks like that, and it’s good in regards to website performance; by having a common CDN it makes it almost guaranteed that the user will already have the libraries cached, so your page load times are decreased and cache storage size on the user’s end is reduced.

Using things like that doesn’t make Signal any less trustworthy.

jlund:

It isn’t anymore. The YAML file format is different now too. Watch Transifex for an update soon.

On Transifex, there’s now a line feed symbol as the last character of each string, which could lead to confusion.

I guess these can be avoided by formatting it as (example)

<source>Signal for Android</source>

instead of

<source>Signal for Android
</source>

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

Using things like external scripts and Google fonts doesn’t make Signal any less trustworthy.

No, but

p4nci:

the Signal team unintentionally makes itself untrustworthy

He is talking about the organization, not the app.

And @p4nci is right about that. If you advocate privacy on one hand but don’t take the extra effort on the website, that certainly seems like they don’t actually care all that much about protecting privacy against big tech companies. Open Whisper Systems could become a rolemodel, it’s not showing much intent to be that rolemodel if you look at signal.org.

And would it really be such a major impact on performance /andoperating costs that it is not worth the extra effort of self-hosted fonts and scripts?

It’s not even an illusion that Google and other companies can make use these external resources to fingerprint users. It’s really happening. I think some users would very much appreciate if OWS steppes up to be a rolemodel on their websites as well, by removing external resources. It could improve the level of trust some users have in the organization Open Whisper Systems.
Why not remove external resources? Who cares about 1ms extra loading time? Who cares about a slightly higher bandwidth usage on the servers? The downsides of this change are so small.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
Meteor0id:

Who cares about 1ms extra loading time?

Not even close.

Turning off CDN means ~0ms change for those who happen to be connected near the place the signal.org data centers are, but at the same time hundreds of ms for people from other side of the world.

Meteor0id:

The downsides of this change are so small.

And the loading time is also in reverse proportion to the internet speed. Many people don’t have fiber (what you are probably thinking of), don’t even have an average network speed. This could mean seconds. 2-3 seconds and we will lose a potential Signal user, possibly forever!

jlund:

…it does not automatically change to German. I have to manually change the setting. Is this the way you want this page to work?

This should be fixed now.

Partially. If language is “German [de]” then web page loads in German, excellent fixed. But if language is set to “German (Austria) [de-at]” it still loads in English, not good. Probably only first part up to dash of string de-at should be recognized as language, not whole string.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
awaitlink:

This could mean seconds . 2-3 seconds and we will lose a potential Signal user, possibly forever!

I hope it’s irony (which, to be honest, I don’t understand)

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
p4nci:

I hope it’s irony

Well you are mostly correct. However it is a fact that users are likely to cancel page loading if they see nothing appear after 2-3 seconds.

Obviously it depends on what the cdn delivers (i.e. are those files a must-have for the page to show properly). If the website can render quickly enough and then load some unnecessary js in background it’ll be ok.

But this is not the case here. The bare html will look pretty awful if at least bootstrap css hasn’t loaded yet.

So overall my argument is that cdn should be kept. The difference is not in 1 ms but in 100s of ms. Nobody likes seeing bare bones of html without proper formatting.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
Surely you mean the users who wait 10 seconds until the 15 trackers are loaded in the background and then all the popups are clicked away?
Yes, those are exactly the users who don’t want a second messenger, but have at the same time 3 torch apps, 10 “bonus-collector” apps, <you_name_it-app>, … I observe this daily in Metro. Meanwhile they switch between the apps and tap wildly on the white empty display. But certainly others have observed something different.

awaitlink:

The bare html will look pretty awful if at least bootstrap css hasn’t loaded yet.

Then you as a developer are certainly doing something wrong. imo, the webpage should always have a solid basic structure without third-party crap.
btw. I’m seeing the web with different (relaxed) eyes now, since I browse by default without JS.

I think we’re getting more and more off-topic. I just wanted to point that out and nothing more. Personally, I remain determined that for all projects I have to manage, I will always keep everything locally.

posts.name: ⚠️ abandoned account ⚠️
posts.cooked:
Sorry to hijack this topic somehow (again), but it’s about signal.org Homepage, though in other context.

p4nci:

on the other hand “tracking” in signal.org.

Unfortunately it’s worse than you see at first glance: there is an inline JS that tracks users:

<script type="text/javascript">
    var clicky_site_ids = clicky_site_ids || [];
    clicky_site_ids.push(101071404);
    …..
    s.async = true;
    s.src = '//static. getclicky. com/js';
    …..

Of course getclicky[DOT]com try to set a cookie as third-party:

in. getclicky. com | cluid | 1608941341 | 2039-05-02 07:58:12Z

For more info see Analyze | Webbkoll - dataskydd.net

I repeat myself, but at least this should be baned from signal.org.

It is clear that statistics can be useful, but there are “User Privacy Protection” analytic tools for that:
https://matomo.org (former Piwik)
